TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit WindowsTokenRoleProvider extends System.Web.Security.RoleProvider

Docs.summary: Gets role information for an ASP.NET application from Windows group membership.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class is a read-only role-membership provider that retrieves role information for a Windows user based on Windows security groups. It is most useful with ASP.NET applications that use Windows authentication mode where the IIS authentication settings disable anonymous authentication. You can configure ASP.NET applications to allow or deny access based on a user's membership in a particular Windows group.
You cannot use the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class to create or delete roles or modify the membership of a role that is based on Windows group membership. This functionality is managed by the Windows operating system. The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class supports only the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> and <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.GetRolesForUser%2A> methods of the <xref:System.Web.Security.RoleProvider> abstract class.
## Examples The following example shows the Web.config file for an ASP.NET application. It specifies that the application uses both Windows authentication and the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class to retrieve role information for Windows users. The element specifies that only users in the BUILTIN\Administrators group are allowed access to the application.
``` <configuration> <system.web> <authentication mode="Windows" />
<authorization> <allow roles="BUILTIN\Administrators" /> <deny users="*" /> </authorization>
<roleManager defaultProvider="WindowsProvider" enabled="true" cacheRolesInCookie="false"> <providers> <add name="WindowsProvider" type="System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider" /> </providers> </roleManager>
</system.web> </configuration> ```

This constructor is not intended to be used from your code.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Unlike other role providers such as the <xref:System.Web.Security.SqlRoleProvider>, the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class does not associate role information with an application. Instead, the role information is taken from the Windows groups on the local computer. Multiple applications on the same server that use the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class always share the same role information. Although the `applicationName` can be configured in the Web.config file for the application, the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.ApplicationName%2A> property is not used to retrieve role information.
## Examples The following example shows the element in the `system.web` section of the Web.config file for an ASP.NET application. It specifies the application's <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> instance and sets the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.ApplicationName%2A> property to `MyApplication`.
``` <roleManager defaultProvider="WindowsProvider" enabled="true" cacheRolesInCookie="false"> <providers> <add name="WindowsProvider" type="System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider" applicationName="MyApplication" /> </providers> </roleManager> ```

Docs.exception: An attempt was made to set the property by a caller that does not have ASP.NET hosting permission.

.method public hidebysig virtual instance string[] GetRolesForUser(string username) cil managed

public: override cli::array <System::String ^> ^ GetRolesForUser(System::String ^ username);
override this.GetRolesForUser : string -> string[]

Docs.param: The user to return the list of Windows groups for in the form DOMAIN\username.
Docs.summary: Gets a list of the Windows groups that a user is in.
Docs.returns: A string array containing the names of all the Windows groups that the specified user is in.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is called by the <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles> class to retrieve from the Windows operating system a list of the Windows groups that the specified user is in. The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.GetRolesForUser%2A> method can be called only for the currently logged-on user, as identified by the LOGON_USER server variable. If the value supplied in the `username` parameter is not the name of the currently logged-on user, a <xref:System.Configuration.Provider.ProviderException?displayProperty=nameWithType> is thrown.
For more information an ASP.NET and Windows authentication, see [ASP.NET Authentication](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/fc10b0ef-4ce4-4a7f-9174-886325221ee1(v=vs.100)).
## Examples The following code example uses the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.GetRolesForUser%2A> method to retrieve a list of roles for a specified user and binds the list of roles to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control. For an example of a Web.config file that enables role management, see <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/CS/viewrolescs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/VB/viewrolesvb.aspx#1)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.Initialize%2A> method initializes the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> class with the property values specified in the ASP.NET application configuration file (Web.config) and is not intended to be used directly from your code.

MemberSignature.Value: public bool IsUserInRole (string username, System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole role);
.method public hidebysig instance bool IsUserInRole(string username, valuetype System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole role) cil managed
Public Function IsUserInRole (username As String, role As WindowsBuiltInRole) As Boolean
public: bool IsUserInRole(System::String ^ username, System::Security::Principal::WindowsBuiltInRole role);
override this.IsUserInRole : string * System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole -> bool

Docs.param: The user name to search for in the form DOMAIN\username.
The Windows role to search in.
Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the specified user is in the specified built-in Windows role.
Docs.returns: if the specified user is in the specified Windows role; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method enables you to check whether a user is in one of the common Windows roles described by the <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole> enumeration. This method is useful for applications that are localized into multiple languages. This overload of the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method is not part of the <xref:System.Web.Security.RoleProvider> base class and can only be accessed by casting the <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles.Provider%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles> class as the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider> type.
You can call the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method only for the currently logged-on user, as identified by the LOGON_USER server variable. If the value supplied in the `username` parameter is not the name of the currently logged-on user, an <xref:System.Web.HttpException> is thrown.
<xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method can only be called for the currently logged-on user identified by the LOGON_USER server variable. The current logged on user must be a Windows authenticated user. For more information on ASP.NET and Windows authentication, see [ASP.NET Authentication](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/fc10b0ef-4ce4-4a7f-9174-886325221ee1(v=vs.100)).
## Examples The following code example programmatically checks whether the currently logged-on user is in the Administrators role before allowing the user to view roles information for the application. For an example of a Web.config file that enables role management, see <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/CS/ViewRoles2cs.aspx#2)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/VB/ViewRoles2vb.aspx#2)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method is called by the <xref:System.Web.Security.Roles> class and the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal.IsInRole%2A> method of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.User%2A> property to determine whether a user is in a Windows group. You can call the <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider.IsUserInRole%2A> method only for the currently logged-on user, as identified by the LOGON_USER server variable. The current logged-on user must be a Windows authenticated user. For more information on ASP.NET and Windows authentication, see [ASP.NET Authentication](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/fc10b0ef-4ce4-4a7f-9174-886325221ee1(v=vs.100)).
## Examples The following code example programmatically checks whether the currently logged-on user is in the Administrators role before allowing the user to view roles information for the application. For an example of a Web.config file that enables role management, see <xref:System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider>.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/CS/viewrolescs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Security.WindowsTokenRoleProvider/VB/viewrolesvb.aspx#1)]
